title: What are the differences between Plato and Aristotle in political thoughts? - Quora

response.answer_text: We don’t know Plato’s political thoughts, because the Republic — usually considered the main source of information on that topic — is actually an allegory for the right governance of the individual soul. The elements and operations of the soul are likened to a highly artificial city; all the specific details of that city, including things like communism and social classes, are subordinated to his metaphorical purpose. Hence none can be considered representative of Plato’s actual political views. In his Book 2 of his Politics, Aristotle reviews and criticizes Plato’s political theories. However the consensus is that he is unusually and inappropriately literal in his interpretation of the Republic, and mostly uses it as a foil to present his own theories. In any case, Aristotle comes out strongly in favor or aristocracy as a form of good civil government. Plato’s views we can, in truth, merely guess at. Possibly, having seen virtually every form of government fail in Athens, he may have been skeptical that any system can work as long as people remain foolish and unvirtuous.
